all_paragraphs: Capital One is one of the largest American banking holding companies with over $370 billion in assets as of 2018, 755 branches, and 2000 ATMs. It’s ranked 98th on the Fortune 500 and has a market share of 5%. As of 2016, Capital one had 62.5 million active cardholders which make for a plethora of data.

Uncoincidently, Capital One has been remarked as a leader in data and analytics. In 1988, Capital One disrupted the credit card industry by individually personalizing every credit card offer using statistical modeling and relational databases. Now, Capital One is leveraging modern technologies and data scientists to create a new wave of disruption.

Data Scientists at Capital One are helping to lead the next wave of disruption in the finance industry. Projects can range from building new fintech projects on a Capital One Labs’ team to improving existing products and services.
The interview process at Capital One is quite rigorous and is composed of a number of steps:

The interview starts off with an initial phone screen which is usually 30 minutes long. This stage is led by a recruiter and is simply conducted to get a better understanding of each other. The recruiter will typically give you a walkthrough of the role and the interview process, and they’ll also ask you standard questions about your resume and past experiences. They want to see that you have an interest in Capital One and that you have the experience and competency that’s required for the role.

After the phone screen is the technical round, which is also conducted through the phone. This stage is about one hour long and does not consist of any coding. In this stage, the interviewer will either…
Sample Case: Given a dataset on customer calls and agents, talk about how you would prepare the data and model the data to improve the qualities of customer service.
Want more real-life data science interview questions from Capital One with solutions? Find more on Interview Query.

In this stage, you’re given a week to complete a take-home data challenge. In this stage, you’ll demonstrate your ability to code, model, and solve a real-life problem. Here, you’ll be given a dataset and will be asked to clean the data and build a predictive model on the data to achieve a predetermined goal.
To give an example, previous candidates were given an NYC taxi dataset and were asked to build a model to predict how much a driver would receive in tips.

After the data challenge is the onsite interview. There are usually three to five rounds of interviews and each round lasts around one hour. The types of interviews vary from behavioral interviews to technical interviews to business cases.

Behavioral: In the behavioral interview, this is where you’ll be asked a number of situational questions that typically start with “tell me about a time”. Make sure you use the STAR format (situation, task, action, result) when answering these questions and be concise!

Whiteboarding/Technical: The technical round(s) can differ greatly — typically, this round will be composed of technical questions on statistics and machine learning or this round is used to solve a whiteboarding problem.

In terms of statistical questions, previous candidates were asked questions on regression, correlations, multicollinearity, p-values, etc… In terms of machine learning questions, the questions will be similar to the technical phone screen.

Business Case: This part of the interview is less focused on data science and more focused on business understanding. The interviewer will provide you with a case and will ask you several business-related questions.

Previous example: Given a car loan case, what are the revenues? expenses? Given a model that predicts whether a customer is good or bad, find out the probability that the customer is good given the model predicts good, the probability that a customer is bad given the model predicts good, etc…

Job Fit: One of the rounds will be focused on whether you’re “fit” for the role, the team, and the company overall. Here, the interviewer will talk about the department, the projects that you’ll be working on, and will get an understanding of who you are and whether you’ll integrate well with the team or not.
If you’re interested in other company guides, check out the Google, Facebook, and Amazon data science interviews questions.
